Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that wearing masks is one of the most effective means of preventing the transmission of COVID-19, as supported by scientific studies and health researchers.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the findings of the CDC report by suggesting that wearing masks increases the likelihood of contracting COVID-19, when the report actually found a correlation between regular mask wearing and lower transmission.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it misinterprets a survey from the CDC and does not provide sufficient evidence to support the assertion that wearing masks collects the virus.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption that wearing masks leads to the collection of the virus, without providing any scientific evidence or logical reasoning to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations for the higher percentage of infected people wearing masks, such as the fact that mask-wearing individuals may be more cautious and exposed to higher-risk situations.
